channel.title: Reason for arrays?
channel.description:
So all I understand about them is they are more ''efficient." I don't know what causes the efficiency either as I usually use Enums over Arrays in situations like skills and emotes, but when I just need them to hold data to loop through I use them. I want to know how exactly they are better and why they are better. I loop different arrays to load on each initialization for each person logging in and was wondering is this going to cause any memory issues?
I've been able to achieve this using arrays and a few if statement checks. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gx7V1qe0920

item.title: Reason for arrays?
item.dc:creator: @Uncalled Uncalled
item.description:
@Uncalled wrote:

[quote=“RiiPiiNFtW, post:7, topic:468207”][quote author=Whackatre link=topic=585168.msg4158870#msg4158870 date=1352875509]
learn about efficiency before you ramble on about concepts you don’t actually have a clue about ok thanks bye

(also i recommend you to get your terms and definitions correct; design != efficiency)
[/quote]I’m not rambling on about efficiency. This thread isn’t meant to lecture on how good arrays are, its a thread for me to learn and people to discuss. I want to see opinions.

Also, design == efficiency if you know what you’re doing. I am confident that I am doing things as efficient as possible. kthxbai[/quote]efficiency relies on design - design != efficiency.

Read full topic

item.title: Reason for arrays?
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“RiiPiiNFtW, post:7, topic:468207”][quote author=Whackatre link=topic=585168.msg4158870#msg4158870 date=1352875509]
learn about efficiency before you ramble on about concepts you don’t actually have a clue about ok thanks bye

(also i recommend you to get your terms and definitions correct; design != efficiency)
[/quote]I’m not rambling on about efficiency. This thread isn’t meant to lecture on how good arrays are, its a thread for me to learn and people to discuss. I want to see opinions.

Also, design == efficiency if you know what you’re doing. I am confident that I am doing things as efficient as possible. kthxbai[/quote]

sometimes, but not necessarily. a common misconception among moparscapers is about efficiency and it seems like hardly any of you seem to really understand it at all. using a for loop versus performing each statement individually isn’t necessarily faster. yes, it might be indeed better practice but no, not any faster.

for starters if you are interested in efficiency (which i probably don’t think you are but just incase), you could read up on the big O notation: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_O_notation

and i also dislike the fact that you are comparing apples to oranges. why not compare two similar objects with an actual similarity, such as arrays and arraylists? then you could easily debate on design patterns and whatnot.

[quote=“RiiPiiNFtW, post:5, topic:468207”][quote author=Team_Rocket link=topic=585168.msg4158825#msg4158825 date=1352869770]

It depends on your needs really.

I believe this is another “Arrays V.S. Enums” Thread.
[/quote]No, I am confident with how I use enums. I want to know whats behind the arrays. I use them just for looks and its easier listing numbers in 1 array, strings in another array and then using a loop and one line of code to do it instead of 100 lines. Saves space. :P[/quote]

then perhaps you should read how arrays are handled in memory. it’s a very simple concept that i think even you can comprehend perfectly. if you are so interested in how they work, why not read it up? here is one explanation which i think you may find fairly useful: http://www.brpreiss.com/books/opus5/html/page82.html

Read full topic

item.title: Reason for arrays?
item.dc:creator: @RSPS_Mirrors RSPS Mirrors
item.description:
@RSPS_Mirrors wrote:

I always find that people will always argue the pros and cons of what’s more efficient. Other factors come into play with every scenario, so my best advice is to use what you prefer/feel more comfortable with. I wouldn’t worry over minute efficiency differences if I was you, unless you’re doing something major (networking, entity updating etc.).

Read full topic

item.title: Reason for arrays?
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

er well I could be wrong cause I am an idiot but I am pretty sure enums are better than arrays.

True though, you won’t see a real difference most likely in rsps related items at least cause it doesn’t haven’t to search for that many items.

with an array string it would have to go through the string until it ended or found whatever.

with an enum it’s going to somewhat “hop” to it if I remember correctly.

Does that make sense cutie? <3

Lesson #2: hashmaps…o wait

but seriously, I am not sure how true this is or not but I believe somehow enums are static in a sense (somebody confirm/deny ~^ ) IF it is true, then it may not be best to use an enum for whatever type of grouping your doing.

keep in mind that an array is a group of same items(i.e. pickaxes) while enums are different (i.e. slayer monsters ) So they both have their respective uses

Read full topic

item.title: Reason for arrays?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

It depends on your needs really. Enums should represent limited sets of objects. Such as planets, colors, etc. Arrays are just groups of objects, not necessarily specific things.

Read full topic

item.title: Reason for arrays?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

You have to have some structure which you use to hold data for content. In Ruby I use the builder pattern to create objects which then I use to access data. Which just makes it easier to read and manipulate. Then I have a mapping of an identifier for the object I create using the builder. It’s simple, clean, effective, but I’d like to see someone create a solution for this in Java since I’ve never tried to.

Read full topic
